Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Socio-Political Consequences of Producing Workers through Migration and Training

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Government funded and initiated development policies and programs can be key drivers of both domestic and international migration, both in the United States and abroad. The goals and effects of such policies and programs vary depending on the target population. For ethnic minority women, recruitment into domestic and personal service labor is common. Because of the intimate nature of such work, it is often accompanied by training programs designed to prepare workers to meet the requirements of both the government and employers. However, little is known about how the programs achieve their goals, how they transform ethnic minority women into desirable employees, and how that transformation affects the women themselves, particularly given that employment in these sectors is prone to instability, unpredictability, and vulnerability. The anthropological research funded by this award is designed to fill this gap by following a cohort of such women through their migratory journeys, interactions with government officials, involvement with government funded programs, and labor in the care sector.

The research will be conducted in India by Brown University doctoral student Andrea L. Wright, under the supervision of Dr. Lina Fruzzetti. India is ideal for these research questions because, unlike the United States, all locations in the labor chain are in one country, which facilitates control of variables for data collection and analysis. The researcher will focus on women from the northeastern state of Manipur who migrate, with government encouragement and support, over 2000 miles south to the city of Bangalore for training and employment. Because of the violence and discrimination that such women have experienced in Bangalore, they present a particularly compelling research population. The researcher will monitor a selected group of women throughout the training course and into their post-training employment. She will collect data using a mixed methods approach, including: participant observation ethnography; semi-structured interviews with a representative sample of all stakeholders (government official, trainers, trainees, employees, industry representatives, non-governmental organizations, families) in both Manipur and Bangalore; focus group interviews; event analysis of relevant industry fairs; document analysis; and analysis of trainees' work diaries. The results of this research will contribute to social science theory of how and why workers of a specific type are created through targeted training. Results also will provide policy makers with information they need to design programs that serve the needs of those who are trained as well those who sponsor the training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research is an eighteen-month multi-sited ethnographic study in India to explore the processes that drive women migration from the Northeast region of India to Bangalore and the transformations they undergo as migrants, beauty therapy trainees, and laborers. The fieldwork was conducted in Bangalore (Karnataka) and Kohima and Dimapur (Nagaland). The central question driving this study is: Through what processes and with what outcomes are women from a minority ethnic socio-cultural background transformed -- through migration, training, participation in a local community activities, and employment -- into professionals who are accepted by employers and relatively higher ranking women in a majority socio-cultural setting to provide body care in intimate relations?

In order to answer this question, my research pursued four major questions through participant observation and open-ended interviews: 1) How has increased growth in the beauty product market and increased demand for beauty services affected the desire for and recruitment of Northeast women as intimate laborers? 2)? What does the overrepresentation of Northeast women as beauty laborers in Bangalore reveal about the significance of ethnicity in maintaining labor hierarchies in contemporary India, and what are the strategies that vulnerable female migrants deploy to cope with the discrimination and ethnic violence they encounter as intimate laborers and ethnic minorities? 3) What constitutes transformation into a professional laborer for Northeast women and how are these women transformed through processes of migration, beauty therapy training, and employment? 4) What are the factors both in the Northeast (particularly the states of Manipur and Nagaland) and Bangalore that facilitate/necessitate/encourage migration?

The major activities undertaken during the current reporting period include open-ended interviews, participant observation and archival data collection and analysis.  Over eighteen months of fieldwork, I conducted more than 100 interviews and participant observation of over 75 community/professional/social/religious events. I spent more than ten months working in two local salon/spa chains and completed a one-month beauty therapy training course that consisted of over eight hours of training each day. In total, my research produced over 500 pages of typed field notes.

This project brings to the surface a contemporary form of migration for development that moves women across vast distances to hostile landscapes for skills trainings and employment. Importantly, these women are strategically moved from regions of India that are considered politically threatening, ethnically marginalized, non-integrated, and a serious threat to national sovereignty. This project, therefore, connects the anthropological literature on migration and development to that of ethnic citizenship thus creating new pathways for understanding how development is a tool for relocating dangerous bodies to places and spaces in which they can (or cannot) be transformed into proper citizens.

The literature on labor has primarily focused on the processes of laboring and the geographies of the workplace, with those aspects of the training largely overlooked. Yet, given the emphasis on training for work and skills acquisition, the sites, spaces, and processes of training warrant the further attention that I have given through participation in a training course. My research demonstrates how the transformative space of the classroom is used to teach skills perceived simultaneously as natural and technical, and how these trainings link to assumed gender and ethnic identities that extend beyond the classroom. Furthermore, I augment this literature on the importance of the classroom salon by illuminating the purposeful and informative networks built between laborers to pass on the soft skills necessary to position oneself as a trusted professional.

It is not just Northeastern women workers who are omnipresent and yet invisible. Beauty work itself is absent, both in the existing scholarship on development and in the concerns of the Indian and International women’s movement. This is the case despite beauty work being a profession dominated by women and deeply entwined in on going feminist debates concerning gender, care, and labor. In spite of these female laborers migratory journeys and widespread presence in beauty establishments, these women from the Northeast seldom appear in political, social, or academic debates. This project, therefore, brings the experiences of these women out from the shadows.

The key outcome of this research will be a complete dissertation (to be defended in May 2019). Upon completion, this dissertation will be turned into a single authored book and several peer-reviewed articles. At this time, partial results have been shared with the academic community through papers presented at the three conferences. In addition, two academic presentations are scheduled for early 2018. The research findings were also presented at a Research Matters forum at Brown University. In addition, the researcher organized a two-day workshop on safe migration for Northeast community members in Bangalore. Lastly, an 80+ page fact-finding report on an exploitative employment situation at a local spa in Goa was written and is currently being used in a legislative case for better work conditions for vulnerable migrant communities in India.
